title: A Black Man's Personal Journey With Type 2 Diabetes

content: 2005 was one of the most challenging years of my life. I was 54 years old at the time, and it was the year I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. As a Black man with Caribbean roots who ran 6 to 8 miles a day in my teens, 20s, and 30s – but unfortunately in my 40s, I stopped running and exercising like I used to – I became overweight.

I believe one of the many reasons I became overweight was because of my love affair with sugar. In my youth, growing up in the Roxbury section of Boston, I enjoyed what we called the “penny candy store.” These stores were usually within walking distance of your home and had every candy you could imagine – for a penny, or a cheap price.

Even when I ran 6 to 8 miles a day, I enjoyed my sugar fix, I loved candy like Sugar Daddies, Sugar Babies, sugary drinks, root beer sodas, coconut macaroons, sweet tea, sweet potato pies, and other sweets that were no good for me. The fact is, I thought when I exercised, it really didn’t make a difference.

content: Then one day, after drinking three large, sugar-ladened sweet teas in 2005, it all caught up with me. In spite of having generally a decent diet of eating lots of vegetables, limited meats, and plenty of grains, little did I know, my blood sugar levels were hitting the roof. I didn’t feel well, I felt like I was about to faint. I had not eaten all day, thinking it could be an upset stomach. I went for a doctor’s visit. My doctor, who is not a person of color, took a urine sample, pricked my finger, and informed me that my blood sugar level was at 500.

He indicated at that time that I could have prediabetes or diabetes. I didn’t know at the time what diabetes was or what was the cause. Like so many people who learn that they have diabetes, I was petrified. My doctor, who was an internal medicine doctor and not an endocrinologist, urged me to come back to his office in a week. He asked me not to eat any candy, not to drink any sodas, and to limit the amount of bread I consumed, so he could again test my fasting blood sugar levels and A1c.

content: I went back to the doctor's office, and he tested me again. This time my fasting blood sugar level was 360. He concluded I had type 2 diabetes. He placed me on insulin and gave me a 2-minute explanation about diabetes. Then, he gave me what I consider the worst misinformation that a doctor could give to someone newly diagnosed with diabetes. He told me I would have to use insulin for life, and that diabetes is irreversible. He urged me to take my insulin as prescribed, limit my sugar and carbohydrates, and exercise. He also urged me to read about diabetes. When I asked more questions about diabetes and what foods I should or shouldn’t eat, he gave me insensitive body and verbal cues that suggested he was rushed and wanted to go to the next patient.

Then, he told me it would be better for me to learn about diabetes on my own. It was at that point I learned firsthand why there is so much mistrust by Black men of health care providers and the health care system in the U.S. Unfortunately, my experience as a Black man with diabetes was exacerbated by the failure of a doctor to provide me with information that would have helped me cope with the challenges of diabetes.

content: To be honest, I felt confused, overwhelmed, and disappointed with the guidance I received from my doctor. I did follow his guidance and I learned about the many African American/Black health disparities in this country. I learned how health disparities translate into worsened health outcomes that impact quality of life, longevity, economic opportunities, and injustices. At the time there was limited information for Black men to learn how to navigate the challenges of diabetes and the special considerations of race

I didn’t know what was next. In 2005, there were limited resources available in my local community addressing diabetes, particularly for Black men. I researched articles on how to manage my diabetes, learning more about diet, exercise, and the importance of medical support through an endocrinologist, nutritionist, pharmacist, diabetes educator, ophthalmologist, and podiatrist.

content: I learned there is no cure for type 2 diabetes, but I can control it with a balanced diet, exercise, and medicine to keep my blood sugar in my target range. Since then, I have lived with the challenges of type 2 diabetes, including feeling frustrated and overwhelmed with its day-to-day demands.

content: My own experience highlights the need for better cultural competency training of health care providers on listening to Black men, being aware of their verbal and nonverbal bias interactions, and providing Black men with the opportunity to voice their concerns and ask questions without feeling rushed by those who are supposed to be there to help.
Learn, share, and connect with others on WebMD’s Type 2 Diabetes Facebook Support Group.
